This is definitely a source of confusion that surprises many; even some who
have worked some time with JUnit.

Each test in your suite(e.g., test_underScore1) corresponds to a new instance
of child of TestCase (e.g., SomeNameTest).  Examine how a TestSuite is
constructed:
1)statically
public static Test suite(){
   TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
   suite.addTest(new SomeNameTest("test_underScore1"));
   suite.addTest(new SomeNameTest("test_underScore2"));
   return suite;
}
2)dynamically
public static Test suite(){
   TestSuite suite = new TestSuite(SomeNameTest.class);
}
Each test case you add corresponds to a new object.  There interference
cannot take place between test cases.  This also can be illustrated from a
the output of a class I route to demonstrate this,

bash-2.02$ java junit.textui.TestRunner SomeNameTest
Test constructor called1
Test constructor called2
Test constructor called3
.setUp called
test_underScore1
1 Instance of class SomeNameTest
tearDown called
.setUp called
test_underScore2
2 Instance of class SomeNameTest
tearDown called
.setUp called
test_underScore3
3 Instance of class SomeNameTest
tearDown called

Time: 0

OK (3 tests)

So if each test case is it's own class, why not rely on the constructor and
finalize method.  Nothing can guarantee when the finalize gets called by the
Garbage collector but tearDown is guaranteed to get called freeing resources
for that test.  For whatever reason (any takers?) the constructor get for all
tests gets called prior to an tests being running so setUp forces resources
to be allocated at the time they are needed.
